snippet: Faced with declining budgets, the Army has had to cut its force, and, for reasons the Army has not explained, the largest group of officers being pushed out — nearly one in five — began as enlisted soldiers.
abstract: United States Army, faced with declining budgets, cut its force in 2014 to 508,000 soldiers from 530,000, and has plans to trim an additional 20,000 troops in 2015; cuts have largely affected low-ranking enlisted soldiers but are beginning to fall on officers who were clearly intending on making a career in the military.
lead_paragraph: Faced with declining budgets, the Army has had to cut its force, and, for reasons the Army has not explained, the largest group of officers being pushed out — nearly one in five — began as enlisted soldiers.

headline.main: Army Cuts Hit Officers Hard, Especially Ones Up From Ranks
headline.print_headline: Cuts in Military Mean Job Losses for Career Staff

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
